title: Aggies begin season with sweep of Tennessee Tech
description: That‚Äôll do, Ags.
fullText:
If you were looking to wash the taste of a bitter 2025 Texas A&M baseball season out of your moth, this weekend was a good way to start. The Aggies hosted Tennessee Tech for a season-opening series at Blue Bell Park, and dominated from start to finish, sweeping the Golden Eagles by a combined score of 45-14.

Certainly the season was never going to be decided on opening weekend. After all, the Ags swept Elon to begin the 2025 season that ended in massive disappointment. But if you‚Äôre looking for reasons for optimism, the Aggies scored 13 more runs than opening weekend last year, and much more importantly committed no errors after committing five on opening weekend a year ago.

It‚Äôs also safe to say that a lineup that includes both Caden Sorrell and Gavin Grahovac, in addition to a slew of newcomers, has a chance to keep this team in a ton of games.

The Aggies host A&M-Corpus Christi for a midweek tilt at 6 p.m. on Tuesday before another weekend series at Blue Bell Park next weekend against Penn. All games can be streamed on SEC Network+.

title: Brad Keselowski calls Riley Herbst block "one of the dumbest things I've ever seen"
description: Keselowski is now 0-17 in the Daytona 500, and he was critical of Herbst's driving in the final seconds of the race
fullText:
Entering the 2026 Daytona 500, there were concerns around if the 42-year-old Brad Keselowski could even run the full race. He showed up to the track with a walking cane, following a December fall that left him with a broken femur.

But Keselowski quickly returned to form, and was a contender throughout Sunday's 68th running of the Daytona 500 ‚Äî his 17th start in 'The Great American Race.'

Exiting Turn 4, he had a massive run. A push from 23XI teammate Riley Herbst helped Tyler Reddick making the winning pass, but Herbst was still eying 500 glory for himself. He went to the outside of Chase Elliott in the pass for second, but Keselowski was already there with a helpful push from Logano.

As the two drivers went for the same piece of race track, a massive crash ensued across the line with Keselowski finishing fifth, suffering heavy nose-damage. Keselowski was frustrated afterwards, and openly criticized, who at the same time was being praised by 23XI co-owner Michael Jordan for helping Reddick to win the 500.

"That was one of the dumbest things I've ever seen," said Keselowski. "He had no chance of blocking my run. I had a huge run, I don't know if I could have gotten the 45 [Reddick], but I would have liked to have found out because my run was coming fast. The 35 [Herbst] just wrecked us in itself.

Keselowski then added: "I thought, well, you know, a one-lane block kind of makes sense, but to block from the very bottom all the way to the top and wreck yourself and everybody else is just stupid. Very, very stupid."

The positive for Keselowski, beyond still scoring a top five finish, is that his leg felt fine. It didn't bother him during the race, and he exited the car under his own power. "Felt really good in the car, felt really good getting through the crash, and I'm happy for that."

However, video shows that Herbst was holding the middle lane before trying to come up into Keselowski's lane to pass Elliott, but the late block still resulted in a massive crash. In the end, it was another possible Daytona 500 victory slipping through his fingertips, and a winless streak that now sits at 60 races.

To read more Motorsport.com articles visit our website.

title: Four-star RB Cadarius McMiller talks pledge to Oregon: ‚ÄúIt felt right‚Äù
description: Tyler (Texas) High Rivals300 running back Cadarius McMiller committed to Oregon over the weekend, choosing to play for the Big Ten powerhouse over the likes of Arizona State, Baylor, Texas Tech, SMU, Notre Dame, Nebraska, Tennessee, Washington and Ole Miss. ‚ÄúI really like the school,‚Äù McMiller said. ‚ÄúNobody else showing me love like Oregon.‚Äù That [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
Tyler (Texas) High Rivals300 running back Cadarius McMiller committed to Oregon over the weekend, choosing to play for the Big Ten powerhouse over the likes of Arizona State, Baylor, Texas Tech, SMU, Notre Dame, Nebraska, Tennessee, Washington and Ole Miss.

‚ÄúI really like the school,‚Äù McMiller said. ‚ÄúNobody else showing me love like Oregon.‚Äù

That love begins with future position coach Ra‚ÄôShaad Samples.

‚ÄúCoach Samp it‚Äôs a good relationship,‚Äù McMiller said. ‚ÄúIt felt right.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a good dude. I feel like to be a good recruiter you have to have good communication and relationship skills and he has both of them.‚Äù

Rivals ranks McMiller as the nation‚Äôs No. 15 running back and No. 173 prospect overall. He visited Eugene a few weeks ago.

‚ÄúThe coaching staff of course,‚Äù he said of what stood out. ‚ÄúEverybody is cool. They got a good facility.‚Äù

McMiller also highlight the ‚Äúwinning‚Äù program.

‚ÄúThe head coach he‚Äôs a good leader. He knows how to run a program.‚Äù

The 6-foot-1, 185-pound McMiller has 10.2 speed in the 100m dash and as a junior he used his speed to rush for 943 yards and 17 touchdowns with 186 more yards receiving and three scores.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm a run hard running back,‚Äù McMiller said. He can also play in the slot. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not doing all that dancing. I‚Äôm straight downhill into somebody‚Äôs face.‚Äù

Oregon signed Rivals No. 4 ranked class in the 2026 cycle and with recruiting wins like McMiller they‚Äôll compete for another top five haul in 2027.

title: Kansas State basketball reportedly fires Jerome Tang
description: Kansas State has reportedly parted ways with men's basketball coach Jerome Tang after it fell to 1-11 in Big 12 play on Saturday afternoon
fullText:
MANHATTAN ‚Äî The Jerome Tang era at Kansas State is over.

The basketball coach has been fired after four seasons of leading the Wildcats, according to a national report by On3's Pete Nakos and Joe Tipton. The university has yet to comment.

Kansas Stateis coming off a 78-64 loss to No. 3 Houston on Saturday, Feb. 14. The Wildcats are scheduled to host Baylor on Tuesday, Feb. 17, at 8 p.m.

The Wildcats are 10-15 overall with a 1-11 record in Big 12 play. They have six games remaining before the Big 12 Tournament in Kansas City.

Tang's buyout sits at $18.675 million. It was the nation's 12th-largest buyout figure entering the 2025-26 season, according to the USA TODAY Coaches Salary Database. It's believed to be the largest publicly known buyout in college basketball history.

The Tang era at Kansas State began with so much promise after he led the Wildcats to an Elite Eight appearance in his first season, 2022-23, only to take many steps back in the following three seasons.

Tang finished his K-State career with a 71-57 overall record. He made $3.6 million as Kansas State's coach in 2025-26. He was the 29th-highest paid coach in the country a season ago.

Tang has an offset clause in his contract, meaning the coach will be required to make a reasonable effort to obtain subsequent employment as long as Kansas State is obligated to pay his buyout over the next 24 months. K-State will be relieved on a dollar-for-dollar basis, provided the coach receives pay from sources directly related to being a college or professional coach, analyst, or administrator, as long as the pay is at an actual market rate.

The buyout is the largest in Kansas State athletics history. Tang replaced Bruce Weber, whom Kansas State paid a $1 million buyout after the coach resigned following the 2021-22 season. The Wildcats haven't had to fire a football coach since Ron Prince in 2008, when the two sides resolved a contract dispute that resulted in a $1.65 million buyout. The school gave Bill Snyder a $3 million payout upon his retirement after the 2018 football season.

During his Kansas State career, Tang made north of $12.7 million, and will now more than double that with his buyout.

Tang had five years remaining on his contract.

The Tang era started out better than anyone could have hoped for, but the Wildcats have taken steps back each season since.

Kansas State was in the Elite Eight after a 26-10 record, while Tang earned Naismith National Coach of the Year honors in 2022-23. That led to Tang receiving a contract extension.

The Wildcats took a step back in 2023-24, going 19-15 and missing the NCAA Tournament. After that season, Tang was tied to openings at Arkansas and others, which led K-State to give him a raise and more guaranteed money to keep him. That's why his buyout is so massive.

That didn't lead to better results in 2024-25. A drama-filled year saw the Wildcats finish 16-17, while much was made about the Name, Image, and Likeness deals on the roster.

Hoping for better results, playing with a revamped but still expensive roster, the Wildcats are still struggling in 2025-26. After starting the season 5-0 and having a chance to beat Nebraska, the Wildcats have imploded since Big 12 play began. They began league play 0-5, the program's worst start since 1996-97, and never got any better.

Wyatt D. Wheeler covers Kansas State athletics for the USA TODAY Network and Topeka Capital-Journal. You can follow him on X at¬†@WyattWheeler_, contact him at 417-371-6987 or email him at wwheeler@usatodayco.com

This article originally appeared on Topeka Capital-Journal: Jerome Tang reportedly out as Kansas State basketball coach

title: Louisville women's basketball fronted by Laura Ziegler in win over Florida State
description: Laura Ziegler led Louisville Cardinals women's basketball past the Florida State Seminoles in an ACC college basketball game Sunday.
fullText:
Louisville women‚Äôs basketball¬†was forced to deviate from its normal game-opening play ‚Äî a pass in the low post to¬†Anaya Hardy¬†for a quick layup ‚Äî against Florida State¬†on Sunday.

The Seminoles¬†took the look away from the¬†ninth-ranked Cardinals. The only problem was that their double team left¬†Laura Ziegler¬†open. The senior called for the ball and nailed the shot beyond the arc.¬†One minute later,¬†Taj Roberts¬†found Ziegler in the paint for a layup. After one quarter, Ziegler had either scored or¬†assisted on¬†seven of the Cardinals‚Äô¬†eight made¬†field goals while tallying five rebounds.

The first 10 minutes of¬†Louisville‚Äôs ACC¬†game¬†against Florida State¬†(9-17, 4-10 ACC) is what¬†the Saint Joseph‚Äôs transfer has been doing all season.¬†And it yielded a similar result to all but four of the Cardinals‚Äô games as Louisville¬†(24-4, 14-1)¬†took down the Seminoles, 88-65, on Sunday at the¬†KFC Yum! Center.

A day after UofL was projected to be a No. 2 seed in the first¬†NCAA Tournament Top 16 reveal, Ziegler showed why as she helped the team build a 34-20 halftime lead.¬†She neared triple-double territory¬†by finishing¬†with¬†14¬†points,¬†eight¬†rebounds and¬†seven¬†assists. Louisville was +28 when she was on the court,¬†covered¬†every inch¬†by contributing in some way.¬†That ranged from bringing the ball up the floor to battling in the post or getting the outlet pass for a 3-point shot.

Ziegler‚Äôs versatility is something head coach¬†Jeff Walz¬†saw from her film at Saint Joseph‚Äôs.¬†After getting her on campus, he tried her out at the point forward position.

‚ÄúShe passed the ball well," Walz said¬†last week.¬†‚ÄúAnd¬†she handles it well enough that at the 4¬†spot, there¬†aren't¬†many 4 players that are going to pick her up full-court.¬†So,¬†the advantage to her then is like, 'Hey,¬†no one's¬†really harassing me a whole bunch.'¬†And then when teams start to put guards on her,¬†she's¬†bigger than they are so she can see over them.¬†And now¬†we're¬†making the pass up to our guard¬†who's¬†being guarded by a post.‚Äù

Ziegler has been open to any role the team needs her to play¬†and contributes more than just scoring. Her leadership as one of only two seniors on the roster has been invaluable. Beyond the intangibles, Ziegler¬†leads the team in rebounds per game¬†(7.2)¬†and is¬†second in points¬†(11.5)¬†and¬†assists¬†per game (2.9).

Her all-around effort has helped Louisville to one of its most successful seasons over the past few years and will continue to be important with the postseason looming.

Louisville is off Thursday and returns to the KFC Yum! Center to host Virginia at noon next Sunday.

Reach¬†Louisville football, women's basketball and baseball beat writer Alexis Cubit at¬†acubit@gannett.com¬†and follow her on X at @Alexis_Cubit.

title: Rangers‚Äô Miller, Trocheck anchor USA penalty kill in 5-1 win over Germany
description: Neither J.T. Miller nor Vincent Trocheck recorded a point in Team USA‚Äôs 5-1 win over Germany on Sunday, but the
fullText:
Neither J.T. Miller nor Vincent Trocheck recorded a point in Team USA‚Äôs 5-1 win over Germany on Sunday, but the New York Rangers forwards anchored a perfect penalty kill as the Americans clinched Group C in the preliminaries at the 2016 Milan-Cortina Olympics.

TH\he United States killed off all three German power plays and improved to nine-for-nine through three contests in these Games. They are the only team that did not allow a power-play goal in the preliminary round.

3-0! ‚úÖ‚úÖ‚úÖ #WinterOlympics pic.twitter.com/CQkF0QVOeB

‚Äî NBC Olympics & Paralympics (@NBCOlympics) February 15, 2026

Trocheck and Miller composed the first forward grouping utilized by coach Mike Sullivan, helping the Americans shut down a German power play that featured NHL stars Leon Draisaitl, Tim Stutzle, and Moritz Seider.

Miller received shoulder pats for a shot block late in the third period on USA‚Äôs third and final penalty kill. He also connected on a stretch pass with Jack Eichel at the close of the first PK, springing the Vegas Golden Knights center for a breakaway chance ‚Äî although Eichel was denied by German goalie Maximilian Franzreb.

The win cemented a perfect 3-0-0 stretch in the preliminary round for the Americans. They won Group C by three points and locked up the No. 2 seed, behind only Canada, who were 3-0-0 with a plus-17 goal differential atop Group A.

Miller logged 12:37 TOI, and Trocheck played a team-low 9:12 Sunday. Each was even with one shot on goal.

Trocheck has two assists ‚Äî both on game-winning goals ‚Äî and is plus-two in three games. The 32-year-old center ranks third among all Olympic skaters with a 66.7 face-off percentage, winning 18 of 27 draws. Miller is minus-one and failed to record a point in Group C play ‚Äî one of four USA skaters yet to hit the score-sheet entering the quarterfinal.

QUARTERFINALS:

(1) Canada vs (8) Czechia/(9) Denmark winner
(2) USA vs (7) Sweden/(10) Latvia winner
(3) Slovakia vs (6) Germany/(11) France winner
(4) Finland vs (5) Switzerland/(12) Italy winner

Re-seeding will take place for semifinals

‚Äî Elliotte Friedman (@FriedgeHNIC) February 15, 2026

USA earned an automatic bid to the Olympic quarterfinals thanks to the win over Germany. The winner of the qualification play-off between No. 7 Sweden and No. 10 Latvia on Tuesday will face the Americans on Wednesday. Should Sweden prevail, Miller and Trocheck will go toe-to-toe with Rangers teammate Mika Zibanejad.

A German team headed by Draisaitl posed the biggest challenge for Team USA in Group C.

‚ÄúWe need to think of this game as a playoff-type atmosphere,‚Äù Sullivan told his squad ahead of puck drop.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs exactly what we did,‚Äù Minnesota Wild defenseman Brock Faber said postgame. ‚ÄúI thought we played a solid three periods.‚Äù

For the second game in a row, the Americans got off to a clunky start ‚Äî highlighted by an awkward collision between New Jersey Devils star Jack Hughes and USA captain Auston Matthews on a Team USA power play.

Auston Matthews and Jack Hughes had a massive open ice collision üò≥ pic.twitter.com/P0OSRROuD9

‚Äî B/R Open Ice (@BR_OpenIce) February 15, 2026

Eichel appeared to give the Americans a 1-0 lead in the final minute of the first period, but officials whistled the play dead before his shot, after Matthew Thachuk was checked into the crease, knocking the blocker off of Franzreb.

Undeterred, USA struck before the horn sounded to close the opening frame. Matthews sent a beautiful saucer pass cross-ice, setting up Zach Werenski for a sharp wrister from the left dot at 19:51.

‚ÄúThese games come quick,‚Äù Matthews noted at the first intermission. ‚ÄúWe didn‚Äôt love our effort the first half of the game last night, so we wanted to come out and have a good start, and I thought we did that.‚Äù

They carried that momentum into the second period. After Miller and Trocheck helped kill an Eichel penalty 50 seconds into the frame, USA flipped the tables with a power play of their own.

This time around, Matthews got to lead the handshake line, gravitating to the front of the net and getting a stick on a shot from Quinn Hughes at 3:25.

Faber gave USA a 3-0 lead at 17:35, quickly firing a high shot from the point that ricocheted off Franzreb‚Äôs glove and into the net.

The Americans made it 4-0 at 1:55 of the third period on a clapper from Tage Thompson, and Matthews tallied his second with another deflection at 6:46.

Stutzle netted the lone goal for Germany with a pretty snipe at 11:22.

Matthews posted a game-high three points (two goals, one assist) Sunday; the Toronto Maple Leafs star leads all American skaters with three goals and five points in three games.

A two-piece combo for Auston Matthews. ‚úåÔ∏è#WinterOlympics pic.twitter.com/vkQzJrWfJb

‚Äî NBC Olympics & Paralympics (@NBCOlympics) February 15, 2026

USA outscored its opponents 16-5 in Group C play. Of course, tougher challenges likely await them ‚Äî namely, a dominant Canadian squad, fresh off a 10-2 rout of France on Sunday.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs stuff that we need to clean up,‚Äù Faber acknowledged. ‚ÄúBut overall, I thought we got better as the tournament went on, and that‚Äôs what it‚Äôs all about. Now it gets real.‚Äù

USA gets two days of rest ahead of their quarterfinal matchup. Puck drop is scheduled for 3:10 pm Eastern time Wednesday.

title: NFL teams bracing for more trades soon: ‚ÄòThat‚Äôs what (buzz) tells me‚Äô
description: NFL general managers will have to be creative in coming up with trades this offseason.
fullText:
Player trades in the NFL have become more common in recent years, and one NFL insider believes the trend will continue this offseason.

On a recent episode of ‚ÄúThe Adam Schefter Podcast,‚Äù the ESPN NFL reporter said it may be tougher for teams to get impact players this season through traditional means, meaning teams will likely be involved in more trades.

‚ÄúWhen we talk about the draft, and we‚Äôll see how it shakes out over time, people aren‚Äôt all that excited about the draft,‚Äù Schefter said. ‚ÄúWe got a free-agent class that‚Äôs not really deep. We‚Äôve got a draft that is not considered really deep. You know what that tells me? More trades. That‚Äôs what it tells me. It tells me we may get more wheeling and dealing in trades than we‚Äôve had in other years.‚Äù

Schefter added that although he has not heard any specific trades that are brewing, he sees the activity around the Nov. 4 trade deadline as an indication of teams willing to make more deals to fix their rosters.

The trade market could be utilized by teams to acquire quarterbacks. This year‚Äôs quarterback draft class is not projected to be as strong as recent years, with Indiana‚Äôs Fernando Mendoza expected to go as the first overall pick and Alabama‚Äôs Ty Simpson appearing to be the only other quarterback projected as a first-round selection.

Kyler Murray (Arizona Cardinals) and Mac Jones (San Francisco 49ers) are expected to be the top targets on the trade market, with Raiders quarterback Geno Smith also expected to garner interest.

On the defensive side, Raiders defensive end Maxx Crosby could be another player moved, although it has been previously reported that a deal for him could come after he finishes recovering from a knee injury he suffered late last season.

title: Report: Cory Undlin, Jason Tarver, Mike Rutenberg are finalists for Browns' DC job
description: The Browns have narrowed their search for a new defensive coordinator to replace Jim Schwartz.
fullText:
The Browns have narrowed their search for a new defensive coordinator to replace Jim Schwartz.

Mary Kay Cabot of cleveland.com reports that the Browns are choosing among Texans passing game coordinator Cory Undlin, Browns linebackers coach Jason Tarver and Falcons passing game coordinator Mike Rutenberg.

Undlin and Rutenberg interviewed in person this weekend.

Undlin and Tarver have NFL coordinator experience, and both coaches have extensive experience working under Schwartz. That would allow the Browns to keep a successful system in place.

Undlin served as defensive coordinator of the Lions in 2020, and Tarver was defensive coordinator of the Raiders from 2012-14.

Tarver has worked as the Browns' linebackers coach the past six seasons, including the past three under Schwartz, and Undlin worked under Schwartz from 2016-19 in Philadelphia. Undlin has spent the past three seasons as the Texans‚Äô passing game coordinator.

Rutenberg became the Falcons' defensive pass game coordinator in 2025 after four seasons as linebackers coach for the Jets.

title: Jalen Brunson Makes Stance Clear On Jayson Tatum‚Äôs Potential Return
description: On Saturday, New York Knicks point guard Jalen Brunson was asked about Jayson Tatum‚Äôs potential return this season for the Boston Celtics. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a very dangerous player in our league, and so obviously seeing him go down last year, it sucks to see,‚Äù Brunson said. ‚ÄúThe fact that he‚Äôs worked so hard to get to [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
On Saturday, New York Knicks point guard Jalen Brunson was asked about Jayson Tatum‚Äôs potential return this season for the Boston Celtics.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a very dangerous player in our league, and so obviously seeing him go down last year, it sucks to see,‚Äù Brunson said. ‚ÄúThe fact that he‚Äôs worked so hard to get to where he is, and is preparing to come back, is a testament to who he is. Basketball fans around the world definitely are excited to see him come back.‚Äù

Jalen Brunson was asked about Jayson Tatum‚Äôs looming return: ‚Äú

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a very dangerous player in our league, and so obviously seeing him go down last year, it sucks to see.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe fact that he's worked so hard to get to where he is, and is preparing to come back, is a testament‚Ä¶ pic.twitter.com/NHmJ4gJVCD

‚Äî Noa Dalzell üèÄ (@NoaDalzell) February 14, 2026

Tatum has made steady progress in his rehabilitation from a torn Achilles tendon sustained in May 2025 during the Eastern Conference semifinals against the Knicks.

Recent developments show Tatum advancing through key stages. In early February, the Celtics assigned him to participate in portions of a practice with their G League affiliate, the Maine Celtics, at the Auerbach Center. This included his first 5-on-5 scrimmage since the injury, involving rostered players, two-way players, and G Leaguers. Tatum described the session as the next logical step in his plan, noting he felt good afterward and emphasizing a focus on daily improvement without committing to an immediate return. He stressed following the structured progression to ensure full readiness.

Teammate Jaylen Brown offered positive feedback recently, stating that Tatum ‚Äúlooks pretty damn good‚Äù based on what he‚Äôs observed during this phase. Reports indicate Tatum has ramped up activity aggressively, with no setbacks mentioned, and he continues individual on-court work alongside team integration efforts. Celtics president Brad Stevens has maintained a cautious approach, prioritizing Tatum being fully cleared medically and mentally at 110% before any game action.

While a return this season remains possible, Tatum has expressed that he wants to come back at full strength, not as a diminished version of himself. Discussions continue, with no firm timeline set.

title: Doug Gottlieb goes on postgame tirade after Milwaukee beats Green Bay late
description: The UW-Milwaukee Panthers led for less than 2 minutes on Feb. 15, using the free throw line to climb back against their rival, UW-Green Bay.
fullText:
Because the whistles had been so plentiful, Stevie Elam‚Äôs defense in the waning moments had to be perfect.

It was ‚Äí depending on who you ask.

As a foul-ridden contest between rivals came to a close at UW-Milwaukee Panther Arena on Feb. 15, UW-Green Bay guard Preston Ruedinger wisely attacked the rim with his team trailing by a point and the clock under 10 seconds. Expecting at the very least to draw some contact and a whistle, all he instead encountered was Elam stripping the ball away.

The freshman stripped Ruedinger, then sank two free throws to ice a 75-72 win for the Panthers to avoid what would have been the first sweep to their in-state foes since 2018-19.

"He had to get that ball pretty clean," Milwaukee head coach Bart Lundy said. "They were driving with force. We had a couple plays before that where it looked like we stopped them and we did get whistled. But Stevie Elam's strength as a true freshman, his hand strength is off the charts; it's probably NFL-level."

Lundy's counterpart disagreed, to say the least.

"The last play of the game, just to get the ball they were grabbing us and holding us," Phoenix head coach Doug Gottlieb said. "Again, I understand if you're not calling that, that's fine. You had the exact same play at both ends in the last play of the game."

Gottlieb paused, ever so briefly, then aggressively slammed his fists into the table atop the dais.

"The exact same [expletive] play," Gottlieb yelled. "The exact same play."

Gottlieb was fed up with the officiating crew from the afternoon after receiving a technical foul and seeing his team shoot 18 free throws compared to Milwaukee's 37. He specifically called out the technical he received in the second half with just under 7 minutes to play and his team up three, as well as a loose-ball foul on CJ O'Hara with 4:25 to go and his team up four.

"I need the new commissioner of the Horizon League to explain to me what a technical foul is when I don't leave the box, I don't curse, I'm not demonstrative," Gottlieb said. "There was nothing, nothing that should have been called a technical foul. I know when I earn one. I did not earn one. The CJ play, we're up [four] points, that dramatically changed the [trajectory] of the game."

Postgame tirades aside, the Panthers had to overcome a huge night from Green Bay‚Äôs Marcus Hall to do so, as the junior from Schofield, Wisconsin, had 32 points and seven rebounds.

Central to Milwaukee‚Äôs efforts in doing so: free throws and Chandler Jackson, who scored 23 points.

Twenty-four of the Panthers' free throws came in the second half, and they hit 22 of them ‚Äì despite being one of the worst free-throw shooting teams in the country at 68.5% entering the day.

Milwaukee led for only 1 minute, 53 seconds in total.

After cutting the lead to one three times prior in the final minutes, the Panthers took the lead with 69 seconds left when Esyah Pippa-White was fouled going for a defensive rebound and hit a pair of free throws.

On the other end, Hall corralled his own miss and laid it back up with 45 seconds left to put the Phoenix up 72-71.

But Amar Augillard wisely drove to the basket on the other end, where he drew a foul much to Gottlieb's chagrin and hit Milwaukee‚Äôs 19th and 20th free throws of the half.

"Our end, [if] you don't want to call a foul, he drove into traffic, whatever," the Phoenix second-year coach and former radio host said. "It's the exact same play as the other end. Could not be more similar. And yet every time they drove in there it was a foul, and every time we did it was a miss."

Milwaukee shot 19 more free throws than Green Bay despite drawing only five more fouls.

Jackson went 8 for 8 from the stripe as he finished two points shy of his career-high of 25 points, which he set in Milwaukee‚Äôs most recent game, Feb. 10 at IU Indy.

Initially thought of as a likely redshirt candidate, Jackson has become arguably the heavily injured Panthers' most-consistent scorer of late. He‚Äôs averaging 14.1 points over his past eight games.

"To see Chandler from June to where he is now, he's just a different guy, different player," Lundy said. "When we inserted Chandler, we really inserted him for his communication. He helps everyone get better defensively. That's what got him the opportunity and everything has grown from that. It wasn't like he was in practice scoring at will on everyone. He talked. He communicated. He cared."

Elam was the only other Milwaukee player to reach double-digit scoring, finishing with 11 points.

With the win, the Panthers moved a half-game clear of Youngstown State and Cleveland State for eighth place in the Horizon League, which matters because the 10th and 11th place teams face off in a play-in for the conference tournament.

Green Bay left the building, meanwhile, in a tie for third ‚Äì and forcefully demanding answers from the conference.

"All we ask is that there's a fair game. That's what we ask," Gottlieb said. "CJ O'Hara goes and gets an offensive rebound, their player dives at his legs and CJ gets called for a foul. I need [Jill Bodensteiner] at the league, our new commissioner, to explain to me the disparity in the officiating. That's what I need explained to me.

"I have no problem with their team, their staff. They played hard. They did what they do. They played tough and they played aggressive. I need somebody to explain to me, just those two. There are others I have massive issues with, including every time we touched them there was a foul in the second half."

This article originally appeared on Milwaukee Journal Sentinel: Doug Gottlieb goes on postgame tirade after Milwaukee beats Green Bay

title: Notre Dame 79, NC State 67: Irish made the Wolfpack turn the ball over until they submitted
description: Notre Dame plays some of its best defense of the season as they try to surge late in the season.
fullText:
The up and down Notre Dame women‚Äôs basketball team did a great job inside Purcell Paviliomn to take down the 3rd place NC State Wolfpack in a 79-67 ACC matchup.

Irish Dominate NC State In 79-67 ACC Victory

SOUTH BEND, Ind. ‚Äì¬†¬†The Fighting Irish turned in a complete performance in a commanding 79-67 win over NC State on Sunday afternoon inside Purcell Pavilion in a game sponsored by Beacon Health System.

The victory improves Notre Dame‚Äôs record to 16-9 on the season and 8-6 in ACC play with four games remaining in the regular season.

The Irish featured a balanced offensive attack in the win, with four players scoring 13 or more points. Hannah Hidalgo led the way with 19 points to go along with eight rebounds, six steals and six assists. Cassandre Prosper and Iyana Moore each scored 14 and Malaya Cowles added 13.

The Irish never trailed in the first frame and led by as many as eight at 10-2 just 4 minutes into the contest before holding a three-point advantage with the score 17-14 following the opening 10 minutes of play. Hidalgo led Notre Dame with seven points in the quarter.

NC State made a layup to start the second quarter to cut the Irish lead to one but Notre Dame roared back by scoring eight straight to push the advantage to nine at 25-16. Gisela Sanchez connected on two shots from beyond the arc to spur the run.

The Wolfpack connected on a jumper to trim the Irish advantage to seven and then Notre Dame took complete control of the rest of the half. The Irish outscored NC State 22-9 over the remaining 7:30 of play to take a commanding 47-27 lead into the halftime break.

All seven Notre Dame players that saw the court scored in the second stanza scored, led by Sanchez and Prosper who each recorded six points.

The Irish shot the ball well over the first 20 minutes of play, going 16-for-31 from the field and 7-of-12 from three-point range.

Notre Dame didn‚Äôt allow NC State to make a run to get back in the game coming out of the half, as it outscored the visitors 18-15 in the third quarter to take a 65-42 lead into the final 10 minutes of action.

NC State managed to score 25 points in the final frame but it was not enough, as the Irish cruised to the 79-67 victory.

Notre Dame‚Äôs defense was everywhere and gave the Wolfpack fits, causing 22 in the win, which marks the most turnovers by NC State this season. The Irish capitalized by outscoring NC State 24-2 in points off turnovers.

Notre Dame improves to 11-6 against NC State in the all-time series.

The 30-point second quarter marks ND‚Äôs sixth 30-point quarter of the season and first in ACC play.

The Irish handed NC State its worst loss of the season on Sunday in the 12-point victory.

Notre Dame finished with 17 steals, marking the 19th time the team has recorded double-digit steals in a game this season.

The Irish never trailed for the duration of the 40 minutes.

Hidalgo has finished in double figures in the scoring column in all 92 games of her career, the longest streak in program history.

Sunday marked the 12th game this season that Hidalgo finished with five or more steals.

Prosper finished with five steals, her second highest output of the season.

The Fighting Irish hit the road for a midweek matchup against Wake Forest at 6 p.m. ET on Thursday, Feb. 19 in Winston-Salem, North Carolina. The game will be streamed on ACCNX.

title: Seahawks hire 49ers TE coach Brian Fleury to be offensive coordinator
description: Seahawks with a stunning hire to run their offense
fullText:
The Seattle Seahawks became victims of their own success this season when the Las Vegas Raiders hired away offensive coordinator Klint Kubiak to be their next head coach. With Kubiak gone, this presented an obvious hole that needed filling in their coaching staff. Seattle was widely expected to promote from within, and understandably so. However, the Seahawks often "zag" when folks expect them to "zig" and they did so once more.

On Sunday, it was reported by ESPN's Adam Schefter that Seattle is expected to hire San Francisco 49ers tight end coach Brian Fleury to be their next offensive coordinator. This was a name that was not on anyone's radar... anyone except Mike Macdonald, of course.

According to ESPN's Nick Wagoner and Brady Henderson, Fleury was heavily involved in San Francisco's ground attack, as his official position last season was tight ends/run game coordinator. Henderson also notes with Fleury coming from the same Shanahan coaching line as Kubiak, the continuity will be kept largely in tact for quarterback Sam Darnold. This was exactly the logic for hiring within, so going with Fleury does make sense in this regard.

Fleury also brings intimate knowledge of Seattle's most hated rival. He's been with the Niners since 2019 in various coaching roles, and of course also knows how best to attack both the Rams and Arizona Cardinals. Although, this will be Fleury's first time as an offensive coordinator, and with Mike Macdonald focusing primarily on defense, he will have a lot on his plate as the one in full control of the offense.

The Seahawks will begin their title defense with a rookie offensive coordinator, but if Mike Macdonald's earned anything it's our trust he's made the right call.

This article originally appeared on Seahawks Wire: Seahawks moves: 49ers TE coach Brian Fleury new offensive coordinator

title: Logan Webb makes his intentions for the upcoming season clear
description: Even though the pitcher has had individual success, he is ready for the team success to follow.
fullText:
Logan Webb makes his intentions for the upcoming season clear originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

It's been four seasons since the San Francisco Giants made the postseason, and during that 2021 playoff run, they suffered a crushing defeat to the Los Angeles Dodgers in five games of the NLDS.

That was the team's standout pitcher. Logan Webb's third season, which has been the only postseason appearance of his career, is entering his eighth season, and the ace is ready for that to change.

"I'm tired of finishing around .500. I know fans are tired of it. None of us is happy about it, either. I've been here the longest now, and it's frustrating," Webb exclaimed.

More:¬†Giants sign former Guardians outfielder in late free agent move

The frustration Webb speaks of is justified, since being a mediocre team can be worse than being at the bottom of the barrel, especially if the team remains the same.

However, whenever one of the best players on the team is stating how much he is tired of losing and individual is not enough more and winning is the top priority, it can end up lighting a positive fire under the team to go out there and turn things around, which is what the franchise needs as that 2021 postseason is the only appearance for San Francisco in the last nine seasons, but before that the team had won three World Series titles over five seasons from 2010-2014.

If the Giants don't begin to turn their fortunes around, that could start to upset Webb to the point where he may eventually want to be traded to a better situation. A dominant starting pitcher like Webb does not come around as often as one might think.

Based on the resume that Webb has built for himself, he will be play a huge role in the team having success if that happens this season, especially if the all-star can have anywhere close to the season that he had last year, where he recorded a 15-11 record, 3.22 ERA, and 224 strikeouts, which was good for third most in the league behind only Tarik Skubal and Garrett Crochet.

title: Florida Atlantic men's basketball team loses sixth straight game
description: After starting out conference play 6-1 and sitting in first place, FAU‚Äôs losing streak has now reached six games, and the Owls have fallen to 10th.
fullText:
BOCA RATON ‚Äî Florida Atlantic‚Äôs men‚Äôs basketball team continued its shocking free fall on Feb. 15. The Owls lost 83-81 in overtime to first-place South Florida in an American Conference state showdown.

Kanaan Carlyle, playing for the time since Feb. 1, missed a game-winning three-point attempt in the final seconds to seal the Owls‚Äô (14-12, 6-7) fate.

After starting out conference play 6-1 and sitting in first place, FAU‚Äôs losing streak has now reached six games, and the Owls have fallen to 10th in the razor-thin standings.

More college basketball: Florida basketball makes another statement in SEC race by dispatching Kentucky

Carlyle scored 15 points on 5-for-13 shooting in his return. Devin Vanterpool led FAU with 26 points, and USF (18-8, 10-3) was led by Wes Enis with a game-high 27 points.

After a disappointing loss to Rice on Feb. 11, the Owls were able to go toe-to-toe with the best team in the American, but couldn‚Äôt secure the victory.

‚ÄúI think we‚Äôre going to get hot,‚Äù FAU coach John Jakus said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll keep it going.‚Äù

FAU will be back in action on Feb. 18 for a road matchup in San Antonio with the UTSA Roadrunners.

Here are the takeaways from the latest loss:

Perhaps the most notable change for the Owls was the return of starting point guard Kanaan Carlyle, who has been out for three of FAU‚Äôs last four games due to a calf injury.

Carlyle looked healthy while knocking down 3 of his 8 three-pointers in 36 minutes of action. The junior had a chance to win it in the closing seconds of overtime, but came up just short from beyond the arc.

The Owls‚Äô offense hummed much more soundly than it has in recent weeks. Five Owls ‚Äî Carlyle, Vanterpool, Josiah Parker, Devin Williams and Isaiah Elohim ‚Äî scored in double figures, but it wasn‚Äôt enough to take down the top team in the American.

Nonetheless, Jakus is confident that Carlyle‚Äôs return will make life easier heading into the final stretch of the regular season.

‚ÄúYou can tell with Kanaan back, there‚Äôs a couple things that are pretty distinctive,‚Äù Jakus said. ‚ÄúThere was just a flow of the way we play when they play together.‚Äù

Amid a deflating losing streak, Jakus opted to make an adjustment to the team‚Äôs starting lineup by inserting Parker in place of the struggling Xander Pintelon.

Parker entered the matchup averaging 12.5 points and 7.5 rebounds per game against American Conference opponents and had been particularly exceptional of late, averaging 17.3 points and 9.0 rebounds per game in February.

Parker posted a 13-point, 10-rebound double-double to go along with two blocks. The performance was histhird-consecutive double-double, fifth of the season.

His upward trajectory has been arguably the only positive to come about during FAU‚Äôs losing skid, with Jakus acknowledging the time had come for Parker to start.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs the best freshman in the league,‚Äù Jakus said. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs averaging 17 and 10 over the last five games and we haven't won, so at a certain point I‚Äôm going to make a change in the starting lineup.

‚ÄúI liked bringing him off the bench. I thought there was a punch to that when we were 5-1. It was fun and cute to have him coming off the bench, but it‚Äôs not cute right now. We need guys to perform.‚Äù

USF‚Äôs Wes Enis and Joseph Pinion did their best ‚ÄúSplash Brothers‚Äù impression, knocking down a combined nine three-pointers. In the first half, it was Enis who got hot from downtown, scoring 18 of his 27 points while hitting four of his eight three-point tries.

South Florida shot 36 percent from the floor, and 26 percent from three as a team, before halftime, but Enis‚Äô shooting kept the game tight.

In the second half, it was Pinion‚Äôs turn to light up the Owls from beyond the arc. After scoring 4 points on 2-for-7 shooting from the floor and 0-for-3 from downtown in the first half, Pinion scored 12 points, hitting all four of his shots from three-point range in the latter half.

In a game in which USF made 13 of 39 layups, it was the marksmanship of Enis and Pinion that led to the Owls' demise. Both players hit numerous shots that were several feet beyond the three-point line, stretching FAU‚Äôs defense to the max as the Owls struggled to contain the long-range shooters.

‚ÄúSome of it is the actions, some of it is falling asleep for half a second, and then some of it is the fact that they can invert the floor all the way to the volleyball line,‚Äù Jakus said. ‚ÄúI think the very worst mistake you make is when you‚Äôre too low, and you let them see one go in. If you‚Äôre low, it‚Äôs over."

This article originally appeared on Palm Beach Post: USF Bulls edge FAU Owls in overtime in American Conference basketball

title: Second-quarter explosion blasts No. 7 Michigan past No. 13 MSU
description: Syla Swords and Olivia Olson combined for 47 points to help Michigan women‚Äôs basketball team secure a 86-65 victory over Michigan State, the largest win in rivalry history:
fullText:
Two weeks ago, the No. 7 Michigan women‚Äôs basketball eked out a three-point overtime win in East Lansing against No. 13 Michigan State.

Sunday afternoon told another story. With a dominant second quarter in which the Wolverines outscored the Spartans, 26-9, Michigan (22-4 overall, 13-2 Big Ten) seized momentum and never looked back to defeat Michigan State (20-6, 9-6), 86-65.

‚ÄúThey jumped on us right away,‚Äù head coach Kim Barnes Arico said. ‚ÄúWe weren‚Äôt able to get stops, and then we kind of settled in and really got stops for the rest of the game. Our second-quarter defense was outstanding, but I thought our defense and the way we forced turnovers all game was really exceptional. Olivia (Olson) and Syla (Swords) were both tremendous, but they had a lot of support from their teammates as well.‚Äù

Trailing 21-15 following the first quarter, the Wolverines had to make an adjustment. The Spartans were driving consistently and scoring in the paint ‚Äî all but three of their points resulted from paint points or free throws ‚Äî while Michigan struggled to get clean looks offensively. With intense ball pressure, Michigan State sped up the Wolverines, impairing their shot selection. Despite collecting offensive rebounds, rather than resetting the offense, Michigan failed to convert on a few second chances.

In the second quarter, the Wolverines turned that trend on its head.

‚ÄúSecond quarter, it was wild,‚Äù Michigan State head coach Robyn Fralick said. ‚Äú‚Ä¶ It was a lot of self-inflicted, just playing a little bit sped up, which we hadn‚Äôt early. And then that got us just out of rhythm, out of sorts. I mean, you can‚Äôt turn the ball over that much and be effective. And then in the second quarter, we gave up so many second shots, too, so that makes the game really hard.‚Äù

Instead of speeding Michigan up, the Spartans were chasing an unsustainable pace themselves. They coughed up the ball 12 times, some unforced errors like travels or inaccurate passes, and others a direct product of the Wolverines‚Äô sticky fingers.

Led by senior guard Brooke Quarles Daniels, Michigan ramped up the pressure, pouncing on Michigan State‚Äôs mistakes and converting them into transition points.

‚ÄúThis needs to go somewhere, but (Brooke) needs to be on that Defensive Player of the Year list,‚Äù Swords said. ‚ÄúShe is the best defender in the country. She fuels our defense. She allows Liv to pick up full court, allows us to have a rest, because she‚Äôs picking up the best player anywhere she goes. So she really fuels the way we play, the style of play, the fast pace, the fun pace that comes from Brooke, so her name needs to be heard. She needs to be on any and every list out there.‚Äù

With the Swords-proclaimed DPOY leading the charge, the Wolverines converted 12 turnovers into 14 points, coupled with 11 second-chance points on six offensive rebounds to shoot past the Spartans with a 26-9 second quarter in which Michigan State attempted just seven total shots. The frame was most prominently marked by a stretch from 6:50 to the three-second mark of the first half in which Michigan outscored the Spartans, 19-2.

Michigan State averaged 12.7 turnovers per game, with 20 as its previous season high. With 16 at halftime and finishing with 24, turnovers were the tale of the tape that separated the Wolverines for good.

But that separation factor was compounded by offensive efficiency. Michigan took better shots, and those clean looks were a byproduct of transition offense and success on the glass. Strong ball movement set up Swords, who sank two key triples to punctuate the game-defining run. Swords‚Äô 10 second-quarter points surpassed the Spartans‚Äô total on her own, and combined with an efficient 47 percent from the floor for 24 points overall.

The Swords-Olson tandem electrified a season-best crowd of 11,627 for a combined 47 points, including perfect 12-for-12 combined from the free throw line. Olson‚Äôs trademark midrange jumper and Swords‚Äô splashy outside shots overpowered the Spartans‚Äô defense, taking what was given and exploiting opportunities. Olson finished with her seventh consecutive 20-point game.

With former Michigan great Naz Hillmon in attendance for her jersey retirement, with ‚Äú00‚Äù hanging from the rafters ‚Äî a major reason why Olson and Swords chose Michigan ‚Äî the Wolverines of today put on a show. Securing the season sweep in both the highest-ranked matchup and largest margin of victory in rivalry history for Michigan, surpassing a mark set by Hillmon‚Äôs team itself in 2020, the Wolverines wrote a new chapter in the rivalry.

title: Federica Brignone comes back from torn ACL to win two Olympic gold medals
description: One of the biggest stories for the host nation Italy at the 2026 Olympic Winter Games has been the amazing comeback story for alpine skier Federica Brignone. Many thought she would not be healthy enough to compete on the Italian‚Ä¶
fullText:
One of the biggest stories for the host nation Italy at the 2026 Olympic Winter Games has been the amazing comeback story for alpine skier Federica Brignone. Many thought she would not be healthy enough to compete on the Italian slopes this month.

Brignone is not just a competitor at the Winter Olympic Games at the moment, but a dominant one. She has come away with two individual gold medals with victories in the women‚Äôs giant slalom and women‚Äôs super giant slalom.

Before Sunday no skier had ever won the women‚Äôs super giant slalom and women‚Äôs giant slalom at the same Olympic Winter Games.

It has been accomplished twice on the men‚Äôs side. Markus Wasmeier of Germany won the giant slalom and super giant slalom at the 1994 Olympic Winter Games in Lillehammer, and Herman Maier won these same two alpine skiing events at the 1998 Olympic Winter Games in Nagano.

The reason why this accomplishment is noteworthy is because of the differences between a giant slalom race and super giant slalom race. The giant slalom race is a lot more technical, while the super giant slalom is associated with downhill more, and is a speed race.

Brignone tore her anterior cruciate ligament during a giant slalom race at the Italian National Alpine Skiing Championships in Val di Fissa, Italy on April 3.

Initially, Brignone was diagnosed with a broken tibia and broken fibula. During the operation, it was determined that Brignone had also ruptured her anterior cruciate ligament according to Lena Smirnova of the International Olympic Committee.

Brignone‚Äôs crash in Italy came 10 months prior to Lindsey Vonn‚Äôs spectacular crash in Italy in the women‚Äôs downhill to begin the 2026 Olympic Winter Games.

Brignone‚Äôs super giant slalom win on Thursday came with a time of 1:23.41. She beat her nearest opponent, silver medalist Romane Miradoli of France by 0.41 seconds.

Then on Saturday in the giant slalom, Brignone beat silver medalists Sara Hector of Sweden and Thea Louise Stjernesund of Norway, by 0.62 seconds. Brignone‚Äôs winning time was 2:13.50.

The host nation now has eight gold medals. There is another Italian woman with two individual gold medals. That is Francesca Lollobrigida, who won gold in the women‚Äôs 3000 metres and women‚Äôs 5000 metres.

title: Bayern Munich‚Äôs goalkeeper situation is in good hands
description: FC Bayern has talent in between the sticks.
fullText:
As Bayern Munich continues to balance legacy with long-term planning, CEO Jan-Christian Dreesen offered thoughtful insight into one of the club‚Äôs most emotionally charged questions‚Äî the future of club legend Manuel Neuer and the rise of his potential successor, Jonas Urbig.

Neuer, of course, suffered a calf injury in the team‚Äôs 3-0 victory over Werder Bremen on Saturday and will be replaced by Urbig in the starting XI until the veteran can return. Speaking about Neuer‚Äôs situation, Dreesen emphasized patience and respect for a player whose performances continue to defy time.

‚ÄúManuel will be 40 on March 27. You wouldn‚Äôt believe that if you‚Äôve followed him in recent games and seen how many incredible saves he made. We spoke early on, and he wants to give himself time and we also want to give him and ourselves time. We‚Äôll discuss things calmly during the season and see what happens next,‚Äù Dreesen said on a recent appearance on BR24Sport.

The quote reflects Bayern‚Äôs typically measured approach to transitions involving iconic figures. Rather than forcing a timeline, the club appears committed to allowing Neuer‚Äôs performances‚Äîand his own feelings‚Äîto guide the decision. Given his enduring quality, that restraint feels both respectful and practical. Few goalkeepers in world football history have maintained elite standards so deep into their careers, and Neuer‚Äôs continued influence in big moments makes any immediate succession plan far from straightforward.

At the same time, Bayern is clearly preparing for the future. Dreesen spoke warmly about Urbig‚Äôs development and, perhaps more importantly, the relationship forming between the young goalkeeper and the veteran he may one day replace.

‚ÄúJonas is doing a great job. The chemistry between him and Manu is excellent, which is particularly important. I think Manu has made it his mission to build Jonas up as his successor and pass on his experience to him. You can see that in training when they talk to each other. That makes us happy. Jonas has already shown his great potential in the games he played. He just needs to gain experience through match practice. He‚Äôs played a lot more games than those before him. I hope he continues this way,‚Äù Dreesen said.

This mentorship element is striking. Bayern‚Äôs greatest generational handovers‚Äîfrom past leaders to new cornerstones‚Äîhave often worked best when knowledge was shared rather than guarded. If Neuer is actively shaping Urbig‚Äôs growth, the eventual transition could feel less like an ending and more like a continuation of standards.

For supporters, the message is reassuring on multiple levels. Neuer is still trusted, valued, and performing at a remarkable level. Meanwhile, the club is not standing still; it is cultivating the next era with intention and care.

In true Bayern fashion, sentiment and strategy are moving together. Whether Neuer extends his story for another season or gradually passes the gloves forward, the process appears calm, respectful, and deliberate‚Äîexactly the way a club of Bayern‚Äôs stature prefers to shape its future.

title: Vinicius Junior reveals role in Kylian Mbappe joining Real Madrid in 2024 ‚Äì ‚ÄúI acted as an agent‚Äù
description: Vinicius Junior has had a difficult 18 months on the pitch, but there are signs that he‚Äôs returning to his best level at Real Madrid. He‚Äôs been in good form over the last few weeks, and it comes a...
fullText:
Vinicius Junior has had a difficult 18 months on the pitch, but there are signs that he‚Äôs returning to his best level at Real Madrid. He‚Äôs been in good form over the last few weeks, and it comes at an important time too, considering his uncertain future at the Bernabeu.

Vinicius is out of contract in June 2027, and so far, there has been no breakthrough regarding a new deal. Despite this, he‚Äôs made it clear that he‚Äôs very happy at Real Madrid, as he told Ibai Llanos (via Diario AS).

‚ÄúI‚Äôm very happy. Playing for Real Madrid, having the life I have and my family makes me happy. Being happy on and off the pitch is the best.‚Äù

Vinicius‚Äô form has suffered since Kylian Mbappe joined Real Madrid in the summer of 2024, but according to the man himself, the pair have a great relationship both on and off the pitch. He also revealed that he was pushing the Frenchman to join in the years before he quit Paris for Madrid.

‚ÄúEvery summer I wrote to him: ‚ÄòWhen are you coming?‚Äô I acted as an agent. With Bellingham I did too. I want to play with the best to have more options to win. We spend more time with each other than with our family. We have to have a good relationship.‚Äù

Vinicius also responded to a question on how he manages to keep his feet on the ground after becoming a big name in football at such a young age.

‚ÄúWhen we are very young we don‚Äôt learn to be famous. I came out of nowhere to be famous and not be able to go out on the street. The good side is that people love you a lot, but the bad thing is the press and the rival fans. But I love (rival fan whistles). We train for these games. In the moments of pressure is when the best players stand out, and at Real Madrid, we are ready.‚Äù

Vinicius, who spoke with Ronald Araujo during the Barcelona defender‚Äôs recent break from football, revealed how he takes care of his own mental health.

‚ÄúYou have to listen to everything, not just the good things.‚Äù

title: Miami Dolphins Discussion: What Wins Championships Edition
description: We ask Dolphins fans why they think that in a league geared towards offenses that it‚Äôs defense that win championships.
fullText:
Last week, I wrote a post with a question of the day asking what questions you would like asked. One of the submissions was from our very own sdphinsfan. sdphinsfan pointed out the fact that the NFL has consistently adjusted the rules over the years to favor offensive production. The assumption being that exciting offenses are what the fans most want to see. But despite the league pushing for offensive production while finding ways to restrict defenses, it still seems as if defense wins championships more often than not. It‚Äôs not to say that you don‚Äôt need offensive production in the NFL, but all things equal, the postseason games tend to go to the teams that dominate on defense. This is also somewhat in contrast to the regular season, where a team with a dominant offense can win a high percentage of its games, even while fielding a subpar defense.

So the now obvious Phinsider Question Of The Day is:

In the NFL, where the rules and the game in general are now geared toward a higher rate of offensive production and, in turn, higher scoring, why are NFL Championships still won on the backs of dominant defenses?

Please share your thougths and answers in the comment section below-

title: Implications of the Zac Gallen Signing
description: Our panelists discuss the implications of the Zac Gallen signing, how it will impact the rotation, and more!
fullText:
DBacksEurope: It is probably true that Gallen improves the 2026 rotation. 2025 first half Gallen was probably a worser version of the pitcher that he actually is, but we‚Äôve seen Zac becoming increasingly worse and frustrated over the past few seasons, to an extent where we had to conclude that he wasn‚Äôt the ace we thought he once was (going to be). The longer Gallen was unsigned, the more likely it would be that he would end up in Arizona again. The QO was a no-brainer for me, so I think it is a good signing. Boras probably tried to pull a Montgomery here again, but thankfully the Diamondbacks didn‚Äôt fall for that one. I think there is still a lack of overall quality on this roster that will prevent us from becoming a serious wild card contender.

James: It‚Äôs fine. I don‚Äôt love it. I don‚Äôt hate it. Frankly, there are no better starting pitchers on the market at this point. Nor were there any better pitchers earlier in free agency that were coming for less money. With the team being up against the financial wall they are, I am actually a little bit surprised they took a gamble on bringing Gallen back. But then, they were desperate for another starter and this also helps the gutted bullpen. In that regard, this is a wise signing. Mike Hazen and his staff are mad if they think Soroka is going to be able to provide 120 IP out of the rotation. He might not even reach 80 IP.

1AZfan1: Knee jerk reaction is this is good for the 2026 Diamondbacks. Given the state of the roster (especially the projected IL) and looking around the rest of the NL, the best chance to make the postseason would come through some exceptional individual performances by players well above their projection. Gallen isn‚Äôt likely to be a 3.50 ERA guy next year, but he‚Äôs got a better shot at it then anyone else available on the market.

Ben: This pairing always made sense. He‚Äôs functionally spent his entire career with the D-Backs and he‚Äôs clearly pretty comfortable with the franchise and the environment. That said, this is a floor-raising rather than a ceiling-raising move. Clearly, the rotation and roster are better with Gallen than without him, but it‚Äôs up to him and the coaching staff to try and fix the fact that his fastball went from one of the best to well-below average over the course of just a couple of years.

Wesley: I find it hilarious that he could and probably should have taken the qualifying offer and we‚Äôd be in the exact same position as we are right now.. Outside of that, it‚Äôs fine. Hopefully, Gallen didn‚Äôt spend the whole winter just appearing on podcasts, and actually spent some time sorting out whatever mechanical/mental issue that lead to his disaster of a 2025 season.

Dano: Kneejerk reaction was a booming ‚ÄúMeh,‚Äù with full echoes and reverb. Also, like Wesley, I appreciate the inherent hilarity of it. Beyond that, I expect him to pitch over the season much like he pitched in 2025‚Äìsome good, some bad, truly mediocre performance for a wannabe ‚Äústaff ace,‚Äù but serviceable enough for a third or fourth starter. Hence the ‚ÄúMeh.‚Äù In any event, he‚Äôll likely be better than Soroka would have been taking the mound every fifth day, so that should be nice.

Spencer: It‚Äôs perfectly fine. There‚Äôs upside and floor. The price is adequate in that 2020s Kendrick way. I‚Äôve never understood why fans seem so focused on how he has a negative ego. Personally I‚Äôve never seen that but I also watch from the east coast so I will be first in line to admit I often fall asleep by the third inning (10pm start time when wake up is at 4:15 is just not feasible). I‚Äôd rather have a starter with a chip on their shoulder than not if we‚Äôre talking mid range with ceiling.

DBacksEurope: I don‚Äôt think there is a scenario where E-Rod, with $40MM left on his contract, isn‚Äôt starting for the Diamondbacks in 2026 as long as his ERA stays below 6.00. So, this is probably worse news for Soroka, who will only be here one year. Although he will probably start in long relief, he will see plenty of action with Pfaadt and E-Rod shitting the bed more often than not, providing a podium for him to perform, just like Nelson did last year. Then injuries will occur and he‚Äôll get his starts.

James: I guess it depends on how one defines bad news. Soroka is the one being bumped from the rotation. Expecting him to have been an effective, 30-game starter was always a bit bonkers to begin with. If the team keeps the entire rotation healthy and does not spend a few weeks running a 6-man rotation until someone gets injured, then Soroka goes to the bullpen, where he can provide some heat in middle, low-leverage relief. When the inevitable E-Rod injury occurs, Soroka might get some starts. Or, if he is effective in relief (where he is better suited), they can leave him in the bullpen and bring up Drake.

1AZfan1: Knee jerk reaction here is Soroka is the odd man out of the Opening Day rotation, but that is only provided that there are no injuries during Spring Training. It‚Äôs likely, or at least a coin flip‚Äôs chance, that one of the 6 possible starters will suffer some injury in Spring and the decision will be made for Torey on who will start the year in the rotation.

Ben: I tend to agree with the rest of the Roundtable: Soroka likely is the first one out of the rotation and bumped to a swingman/long-relief role where he‚Äôs had some success over the course of his career. Of course, it‚Äôs near-impossible that these six will be the same starters at the Trade Deadline let alone the end of the season and Soroka will almost certainly get a few chances to start if he stays healthy.

Wesley: Just to further echo what the others have already said, I‚Äôd say Soroka is the odd man out. I am much more comfortable with him as a BP arm or spot starter than I am as part of the starting rotation.

Dano: Soroka definitely, at least if Soroka really wants to reestablish himself as a starter. That said, it seems like he found a good deal of success pitching out of the bullpen, so it might wind up being better for him if he can firmly establish himself as a good long reliever/swingman.

Spencer: Unfortunately I think Soroka will be pushed out of the rotation. Assuming ERod somehow stays healthy. But if the goal is to win games it should be the opposite. He‚Äôs 5 years younger and his overall production is closer to ERods than you might think if you only go off vibes rather than results. That‚Äôs not to say ERod hasn‚Äôt had the better career thus far, but if I‚Äôm going for ceiling and floor, I‚Äôm riding the potential of Soroka knowing he‚Äôs only good for 20 starts at most. That way ERod can try to remain healthier than average by only throwing a few pitches at a time. But I suspect the goal isn‚Äôt necessarily to win this season and therefore ERod will get the rotation spot and Soroka will be risked in the bullpen.

title: Collin Morikawa wins Pebble Beach Pro-Am, ends 28-month winless streak
description: Collin Morikawa ended a 28-month winless streak, securing his seventh career Tour title at the 2026 AT&T Pebble Beach Pro-Am with a dramatic birdie.
fullText:
PEBBLE BEACH, Calif. ‚Äî Collin Morikawa birdied the 72nd¬†hole to win the 2026 AT&T Pebble Beach Pro-Am by one stroke over Min Woo Lee and Sepp Straka.

He ended a 28-month winless spell with his seventh career Tour title, shooting a 5-under 67 at¬†Pebble Beach Golf Links¬†and finished with a 72-hole aggregate of 22-under 266.

Morikawa surged into contention on Saturday, hitting all 18 greens in regulation, pouring in 11 birdies and shooting 10-under 62. How good was Morikawa‚Äôs ball-striking? It was just the third time he hit all 18 greens in his career and he gained 6.472 strokes on the field in approach shots, the best Strokes Gained: Approach number of his career, the best in AT&T Pebble Beach Pro-Am history and the second best in the Shotlink era (dating to 2004).

After a subpar Ryder Cup for Team USA, Morikawa started the season with a missed cut in Hawaii and a lackluster T-54 last week in Phoenix. That made nine straight starts dating to late June without a top-10 finish.¬†But his swing coach, Rick Sessinghaus, gave him the pep talk he needed on Friday night and Morikawa put on a stripe show on the weekend.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs way more of a feel player than people realize. Everybody thinks he‚Äôs kind of a robot, and he is a robot so-to-speak,‚Äù Morikawa‚Äôs caddie Mark Urbanek said. ‚ÄúHe just kind of got back to hitting shots and being a shot maker, and that‚Äôs what he does best.‚Äù

On a day when nine different golfers were within two strokes of the lead as the leaders headed to the back nine, Morikawa made four birdies and one bogey coming home, including birdies at three of the last four holes. But he made a bogey at 17 to drop back into a tie with Lee, who shot 65, at 20 under. Morikawa drove it in the fairway and had 235 yards to the green. Then he had to wait 20 minutes for Jacob Bridgeman to get a ruling, take a drop and wait for his ball to remain still in the wind long enough for him to putt out. Morikawa paced, stared at the beautiful backdrop that is Carmel Bay and sifted through potential baby names. ‚ÄúNot Bogey,‚Äù he later cracked.

Waiting behind the 18th¬†green to congratulate his friend was Russell Henley, who had chipped in at the Arnold Palmer Invitational 11 months ago to edge Morikawa by a stroke. Henley was confident that Morikawa would get the job done. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs got a 4-iron. That‚Äôs his club,‚Äù Henley said.

Added Straka, who eagled the last to tie for second and played alongside Morikawa in the final threesome: ‚ÄúHe's one of the best iron players of our generation probably. He likes to cut it so it makes it even harder with that wind blowing 25, 30 off your left. Yeah, that is a pretty special shot to put it away there.‚Äù

This article originally appeared on Golfweek: Collin Morikawa wins AT&T Pebble Beach Pro-Am, ends winless streak

title: North Carolina baseball sweeps Indiana to open 2026 season
description: North Carolina opened its 2026 season with a dominant three-game sweep of Indiana, showcasing a revamped lineup and deep pitching staff, including a walk-off win.
fullText:
North Carolina opened its 2026 baseball season with a three-game sweep of Indiana that quickly turned into a showcase for both its revamped lineup and deep pitching staff.

The Tar Heels opened the season 3-0, while the Hoosiers fell to 0-3. With numerous first-time starters and key transfers, North Carolina used timely extra-base hits and strong pitching to control the series.

Here‚Äôs what happened in all three games

North Carolina opened its 2026 baseball season with a 9-4 win over Indiana at Boshamer Stadium.

The Tar Heels used three runs in the fifth and six in the sixth to break open a game that began as a pitchers‚Äô duel, with both starters allowing only three hits combined. The win gives Carolina a 1-0 edge in the all-time series.

Right-hander Jason DeCaro took care of business on the mound as he gave up two hits, no runs and struck out seven over five innings while the lineup, featuring eight first-time starters in Carolina blue, found its rhythm.

Transfer Jake Schaffner drove in the season‚Äôs first run with a sacrifice fly before preseason All-America shortstop Gavin Gallaher ripped a two-run triple, the second triple of his career.

Who else but @GallaherGavin to break this thing wide open?!?! 

Triple puts us up 3-0 üò§ pic.twitter.com/s7Ga9j2uxD

‚Äî Carolina Baseball (@DiamondHeels) February 13, 2026

Indiana cut the deficit to two in the sixth, but UNC answered with six runs in the bottom half to put the game out of reach.

Freshman Tyler Howe recorded his first career hit with an RBI double, followed by a two-run double from Colin Hynek and a triple by Schaffner to left-center.

Reliever Boston Flannery allowed one hit over 2 1/3 innings in his longest career outing for the Tar Heels.

North Carolina won both games in its doubleheader sweep of Indiana, rolling to a 12-2, seven-inning run-rule win in Game 1 and walking off 4-3 in 11 innings in Game 2 at Boshamer Stadium on Saturday.

The Tar Heels extended their streak to 12 straight opening-weekend series wins, nine of them sweeps. It was the first time in program history that they recorded a run-rule and an extra-innings game in the same series.

In Game 1, an all-around dominant effort produced UNC‚Äôs first run-rule of the season.

Erik Paulsen had a fantastic day at the plate¬†as he drove in the first run of the doubleheader in the first inning, then broke the game open with a three-run homer in the fifth ‚Äî the Tar Heels‚Äô first home run of 2026. He finished with five RBIs.

First one of the year was a no doubter üöÄ@Erik_Paulsen44 says hello and goodbye! pic.twitter.com/2UVdn9BxJw

‚Äî Carolina Baseball (@DiamondHeels) February 14, 2026

Left-hander Folger Boaz allowed two hits and one run with six strikeouts over five innings.

A six-run sixth, highlighted by a two-run triple from Colin Hynek and another triple from Jake Schaffner, put the game away. The Tar Heels totaled four triples over the first two games of the series, their most in back-to-back games since at least March 2015.

Game 2 turned into a pitching and defense showcase. Ryan Lynch, officially joining the weekend rotation, settled after a first-inning run to work five innings with three hits, one run and six strikeouts.

Reliever Matthew Matthijs, back from Tommy John surgery suffered April 4, 2025, threw 2.1 innings, looked like his old self as he allowed one hit and struck out three.

An error behind him helped Indiana score twice, but North Carolina tied it in the ninth when second baseman Aiden Stewart misplayed a grounder, allowing two runs to score and sending the game to extra innings.

Bonus baseball at the Bosh ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è https://t.co/PywH6xay1u pic.twitter.com/uhmL5RrcQ3

‚Äî Carolina Baseball (@DiamondHeels) February 14, 2026

In the 11th, catcher Macon Winslow launched a 398-foot line-drive homer off the scoreboard for UNC‚Äôs first opening-weekend walk-off since 2020.

North Carolina hosts Richmond on Tuesday at 4 p.m. ET on ACCNX.

Follow us @TarHeelsWire on X and like our page on Facebook to follow ongoing coverage of North Carolina Tar Heels news, notes and opinions.

This article originally appeared on Tar Heels Wire: UNC Baseball: Diamond Heels sweep Indiana to open 2026 campaign

title: 2026 Daytona 500 results, points as Tyler Reddick puts Michael Jordan in victory lane

fullText:
Tyler Reddick became the 44th driver to win the Daytona 500, leading only the final lap to win The Great American Race for 23XI Racing and co-owner Michael Jordan.

Reddick, 30, ended a 38-race winless drought with his ninth career victory in his 219th Cup Series start (his previous victory was at Homestead-Miami Speedway on Oct. 27, 2024.

All of Reddick's Cup wins have come at different tracks. He joins Kyle Busch, Jeff Gordon and Bill Elliott as the fourth driver in the modern era to earn his first nine victories at nine different tracks.

title: Jeff Stoutland‚Äôs Eagles Departure Signals Major Organizational Changes
description: News broke on Feb. 4 that Jeff Stoutland, the Philadelphia Eagles‚Äô run game and offensive line coach, will not return to the team next season. The report from ESPN‚Äôs Tim McManus came as a complete shock to fans. Stoutland has coached Philadelphia‚Äôs offensive line since 2013. During his tenure, he‚Äôs played a key role in developing [‚Ä¶] The post Jeff Stoutland‚Äôs Eagles Departure Signals Major Organizational Changes appeared first on The Lead.
fullText:
News broke on Feb. 4 that Jeff Stoutland, the Philadelphia Eagles‚Äô run game and offensive line coach, will not return to the team next season. The report from ESPN‚Äôs Tim McManus¬†came as a complete shock to fans.

Stoutland has coached Philadelphia‚Äôs offensive line since 2013. During his tenure, he‚Äôs played a key role in developing one of the league‚Äôs best units. Jason Kelce, Jordan Mailata, and Mekhi Becton are just some of the players who greatly benefited from Soutland‚Äôs guidance.

Following the announcement, Mailata, a current star for the Eagles‚Äô offensive line, said he is ‚Äúheartbroken‚Äù by the news. Additionally, veterans Lane Johnson and Landon Dickerson are reportedly contemplating retirement, which is likely tied to Stoutland‚Äôs departure.

This unexpected exit is shaking up Philadelphia‚Äôs offseason plans and has left fans with many questions.

The timing of Stoutland‚Äôs exit in relation to the hiring of new offensive coordinator Sean Mannion may not be a coincidence.

NBC Sports‚Äô Dave Zangaro noted how Mannion‚Äôs staff-building decisions this offseason could indicate a significant shift Philadelphia‚Äôs offensive identity for 2026.¬† Rumors are circulating that Mannion wants the reins of the offense entirely to himself. As he brings in several new coaches and staff members who share his vision, perhaps Stoutland saw the writing on the wall that changes are coming, and he wasn‚Äôt going to be a part of them.

Stoutland‚Äôs frustrations with Philadelphia‚Äôs operation date back to last season.¬†He was reportedly irritated with the¬†Eagles‚Äô offense and his lack of contribution to the group towards the end of the year. In these reports, it‚Äôs said that head coach Nick Sirianni and former offensive coordinator Kevin Patullo had complete control over the offense in the final few games.

Cayden Steele at NJ.com wrote about how the divide late last season played a role in the separation. According to Steele, Stoutland was ‚Äúnot consulted‚Äù enough regarding changes in the run game.

That isn‚Äôt to say Stoutland was blameless. This season‚Äôs offensive line is one of the weakest he‚Äôs coached in his 13 years with the Eagles. However, a lot of that can be chalked up to injury. Johnson missed significant time, and Dickerson played through lingering injuries all year. Still, that doesn‚Äôt explain the regression from Mailata and Cam Jurgens.

But even in a down season, the Eagles‚Äô offensive line still graded as the seventh-best in the NFL, per Pro Football Focus.

Mannion has instead brought in a slew of new offensive coaches. He is expected to incorporate a ‚Äúwest coast‚Äù type of offense, similar to that of Sean McVay or Kyle Shanahan.

Chris Kuper will be the new offensive line coach to replace Stoutland. Some of the other new faces¬†include Josh Grizzard as the passing game coordinator, and Ryan Mahaffey as the Tight Ends Coach and running game coordinator.

Mannion has close connections to Mahaffey and Kuper already. Mahaffey coached with Mannion in Green Bay, and Kuper was a coach in Minnesota in 2023 while Mannion was still playing quarterback.

There‚Äôs been¬†no indication of Jeff Stoutland‚Äôs next move yet. The term ‚Äúleaving‚Äù indicates he may not be retiring, but he could instead try to coach elsewhere.

So what does this mean for Philadelphia‚Äôs offense? Well, big changes are still on the rise. With Dallas Goedert entering free agency and Dickerson still contemplating retirement, the Eagles‚Äô offense could look much different than it has in recent history.

For now, however, it seems that Sean Mannion has the reins, and Sirianni is taking a step back in his offensive involvement. For better or for worse, the Mannion era is off to a polarizing start.

The post Jeff Stoutland‚Äôs Eagles Departure Signals Major Organizational Changes appeared first on The Lead.

fullText:
Boston Celtics superstar Jaylen Brown has expressed intrigue in pursuing combat sports such as UFC once his NBA days wind down.

In a recent interview, JB revealed he has contemplated stepping into the UFC Octagon or a boxing ring, drawing inspiration from his father Marselles Brown‚Äôs professional boxing background.

Brown mentioned the appeal of high-profile exhibitions in boxing that attract non-traditional fighters and boost the sport‚Äôs visibility. At 223 pounds, Brown would probably be a heavyweight.

Brown has already initiated conversations with UFC CEO Dana White about potential opportunities in mixed martial arts, though he emphasized that any such move would come after his basketball career.

Boston Celtics G/F Jaylen Brown says he would like to partake in the UFC or boxing post career ü§î

"Maybe post part of my career, I would love to partake in something like UFC or even boxing. I've talked to Dana White about some stuff"#NBAAllStar26 pic.twitter.com/sBQTgICKZM

‚Äî COMBAT SPORTS TODAY (@CSTodayNews) February 15, 2026

Brown‚Äôs been all over the headlines this year, as his 2025-26 season has been a dominant display.

Through 49 games, Brown has averaged 29.3 points per game, ranking fourth league-wide, alongside 6.9 rebounds, 4.7 assists, 1.0 steals, and 0.4 blocks in 34.2 minutes. His shooting splits stand at 48.3% from the field, 34.8% from three, and 77.5% from the free-throw line.

JB has been on a tear, scoring 20 or more points in 16 straight games. Earlier peaks included a 50-point explosion on January 3 and consistent double-digit rebounding outings. These career-high marks in scoring, rebounding, and assisting reflect his evolution into a more complete offensive force, helping Boston maintain a strong position heading into the All-Star break.
